Is that an Eleven Foot Serpent in Your Lake or Are You Just Happy to See Me?: Ontario Lakes Project

17 Oct 2012

Lac Des Chats on the Ottawa river forming the boundary between Ontario and Quebec has quite a strange and slithery history. Below you’ll find part of an article from the Stevens Point Herald, dated 1882 announcing the killing of an infamous serpent lurking in the waters of Lac Des Chats (sourced directly from Cryptomundo)

But this week we are in a position to announce the capture of what is probably one of the progeny of the original old Chats Lake serpent, which has often struck terror to the hearts of the superstitious river men…. 

<p>
  They succeeded in getting within striking distance of the serpent when Mr. Durgan struck it a blow over the head with his oar. The beast then turned and made for the occupants of the boat, literally churning the water with his tail in his fury. Another powerful and well-directed blow with an oar on the neck of the serpent laid it out dead when it was taken in tow and brought aboard the steamer.
</p>

<p>
  The crew of the boat stretched it out on the rail and measured it with a rule. Its total length was eleven feet, while the body was thirteen inches in circumference. Its jaws were pried open and a pair of compasses inserted, which were opened out to a distance of six inches.
</p>

Now that’s a big snake. Wonder if any other progeny are still lurking in Lac Des Chats. Who’s game to find out?

About us

Hypenotic is a marketing strategy, design & development firm that chooses to use its powers for good. We’re a certified founding member of B Corp in Canada, and if you don’t know what that is, it’s time you do. Since ’98, we’ve helped a lot of interesting people do important things. We create relevant communications and useful experiences. Find out more.
